instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3662: What is 820-3662? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

What is the exact <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage (no battery)?
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS?
Be sure to use original Magsafe 2 charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
thanks for the welcome :)

voltage on ppbus 12.54v no battery
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.32v; SUS 3.32V

using a 60W original magsafe

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> (at same time).
You can use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads, instead of power button.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
just to be sure i short the pads at <RESISTOR>R5116</RESISTOR> and check for the voltage drop.

PS: yeah i shorted at <RESISTOR>R5116</RESISTOR> and saw a drop at  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, i want to be sure to not kill it xD

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.
If detected, you should catch pulse on some big coils too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> no voltage without short, no voltage while shorting, no pulse at big coils

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
You must make temporary short on mentioned resistors pad; like pressing power button.
Do not maintain the pads shorted.

If no reaction, there is PCH related problem.
Check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> and the 4 PCH's RTC signals (DC, not clock).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
yeah i emulated a button press,  <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is 0v pressed or not

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0.035v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.32v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.32v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.29v
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> 3.29v

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 96060, member: 682"]
PCH's RTC
[/QUOTE]
don't quite know which one

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
"the 4 PCH's RTC signals"
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/how-to-collection.60974/[/URL]
Probably good...

"<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 0.035v"
There is the problem.
85W original Magsafe 2 charger for sure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: damn it such a rookie mistake... the one the client always used was the one i was testing with... i wasted my and your time aaaaah, welp i have another one on which i need a pro opinion, will make a new thread

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
so the issue is different... the pc doesn't recognize the battery, that's why it worked with his old charger 60W because it was leveraging the battery before it stopped working... with the 80W the Mac turn on but it has battery symbol with X.

The battery is at 12V but won't turn on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Did you test with known good battery?

Please, open new thread, if you talk about other machine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: this is the same machine, searching for another battery, but it came here with the same issue before

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Be sure <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is good.
Check voltage and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> is 10k

By " SCL/SDA" you mean <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL>?
smbus <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL> 3.4v charger,3.2v battery, 2.3v diode
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL> 3.4v charger, 3.2v battery, 2.2v diode

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
Read again the above linked thread.
This time pay atention to diode mode checking...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
smbus <SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL> 0.54v red on ground
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL> 0.53v red to ground
sorry

PS: If i disconnect the power when the Mac is on it will be on, but if i don't give it power it won't turn on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message:
The values are correct.
Battery is the first suspect there; test with known good one.
Be aware, "new chinese" is not same as "known good".

If you are in laptops repair bussines, get a dedicated tool to diagnose and repair the batteries.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.laptopu.ro/[/URL]
[URL unfurl="true"]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/dealing-with-nlba1-laptop-battery-tester-and-macbook-air-batteries.63433/[/URL]
Is the best tool on the market.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3662</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> missing
threads.message: yeah... we buy only A+ grade batteries, i guess it was the clients power supply, we will change the battery and sell them the correct 85w power supply
